content.description:
A very cool gully inside an overhanging buttress. Pleasant climbing with a few steep sections to keep things interesting.

Found about 600 meters upstream from French Immersion or 200 meters downstream from Hole in the Wall Falls on the east bank of the river. Rap the route.
A few screws. Tree anchors.

Fun, easy climb of ice and snow to a beautiful plateau top out with stunning views of the LSR valley below. Best climbed simu solo or pitching out the first and last pitches of ice.

This route is 750 meters north of the confluence or 200 meters south of French Immersion. Located on the east bank of the river touching down near the shore is a 15 meter waterfall of ice. Climb the ice and follow the gully to the first ice flow you encounter on your right. Continue up this to the top.
A rack of ice screws. Tree anchors.

Steep curtain waterfall. Gorgeous location overlooking Hole in the Wall Falls on the LSR. Will seem much easier late in the season when the ice is softer and it will be a bear in early season.

Located on the west bank of the LSR downstream from Hole in the Wall Falls. Ascend 400 feet of ice and snow to a series of curtain waterfalls over a cave. Take a walk behind the cave and check it out.
Screws, tree anchor.

Pleasant climbing up this long winding band of ice that branches off about 2/3 up. Each finish is about the same difficulty.

Found on the east bank of the LSR about 100 meters upstream from Hole the Wall Falls.
Screws, tree anchor.

climbs.name: Fiddler on the Roof
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes, Marc Hebert and Michel Martin

content.description:
A very unique, aesthetic ice climb. Begin on the short but steep pillar on the left hand side of a large diagonal roof. Ascend the pillar and continue up the ramp toward the final vertical headwall. Pick a finish on the headwall and top out in the trees.

This route is found about 200 meters downstream of French Immersion on the opposite side of the river (west bank).
A rack of screws. Tree anchor.
No text - use the 'Improve This Page' link to add something useful!

Good climbing on a large flowing piece of ice. 

Located on the east bank of the LSR about 400 meters north of Alpine Gully. 
A rack of screws. Rap the route.

This north facing route is often in early and out late. Pitch one is steep right off the bat with well featured climbing on good ice.  The steepness eases off after about 30 meters and turns to WI 3 and then 2. Belay off a tree. Move up through a short snowfield and then climb pitch 2 going roughly straight up for 200 feet of WI 2/3.

Located on the east bank of the LSR roughly 700 meters north of the confluence.
A rack of screws. Tree anchors. No need for v threads here.

A pleasant stroll up a snow and ice filled gully is worth the time because you will find three very unique cave formations in the rock on either side of the gully.

You must climb the first pitch of French Immersion to find this. Look up and left for a gully that disappears into the trees.
Easy solo.

Gorgeous little amphitheater like wall perched on the east bank of the LSR. Steep climbing for the first 10 meters and then it eases off substantially. This climb faces south and catches a lot of sun so it will feel like a WI3 on  a sunny day.

Found 75 meters up river from Grog. 
A rack of screws. Tree anchor. Rap the route.

Max Fisher dubbed this route "Mini Professor Falls". It is a fun little ramble up an absolutely gorgeous gully. Three steep walls of ice between 4 lower angled sections. Very cool features throughout. Highly recommended.

About 400 meters north of the confluence you will encounter a sharp bend in the LSR to the right. As you come around the corner you can clearly see the route and the gully. Climb the gully until you are level with the plateau across the valley. 
A rack of screws. Rap the route or down climb through the trees to the left or right.

Nice ramble up through some cool terrain.

Just before the first pitch of Grog look right and you will see a piece of ice going up through the trees. 
A rack of screws. Rap the route or walk off left or right.

Climb the first pitch of Bobcat and begin up the gully. Follow the gully staying left of the upper pitch of Bobcat until you reach a wall containing four more lines of ice. Lynx is the second line from the left hand side. This is great pitch of ice offering worth the effort to get to. When you top out you will be rewarded with stunning views of the LSR valley below.

A rack of screws. Tree anchor.

Climb easy ice and snow for about 250 feet. Continue up the final 100 feet of ice, quite steep on the right. Three more separate ice flows are found further right, some much harder.

Found almost directly across from the bend in the river where French Immersion is on the opposite bank (west).
A rack of screws. Tree anchors.

climbs.name: Six Dry Feet
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes, Chris MacClellan and Mike Delaney

content.description:
This relatively short pillar packs a bit of a punch. The vertical to overhanging part is only about 50 feet high but it offers some cool climbing that leads to a pleasant little WI3 finish.

Located above the first pitch of French Immersion. Move up and left towards an east trending gully and you will see a golden pillar of ice on your right.
A rack of screws. Tree anchor.

This is a fun ramble up the narrow staircase like line below the roof.

Located directly below Fiddler on the Roof. Climb the long angling ramp to the trees.
A rack of screws.

climbs.name: Technicolor Playground
climbs.fa: Gavin MacNamara and Anne Giles, Feb. 2020

content.description:
Very aesthetic wall of ice on the west bank located about 250 meters upstream from Alpine Gully. Choose a line on a wide wall of blue ice. 

Perched about 30 meters above the shoreline of the river, 250 meters upstream of Alpine Gully on the west side of the LSR. 
A few screws. Tree anchor.

climbs.name: Too Adult To Party
climbs.fa: Gavin MacNamara and Anne Giles, Feb. 2020

content.description:
Short wall on west bank, near the shoreline of the river. Ascend a broad curtain to the trees.

Located about 300 meters downstream of Alpine Gully on the west bank of the LSR. 
A few screws. Tree anchor.

climbs.name: UB40
climbs.fa: Max Fisher, Greg Hughes and Craig Norris

content.description:
Fun climbing through moderate ice. 

Start up Grog. After about 20 meters in the gully you will see a long wall on your right with ice. Follow the flows to the top of the plateau.
A rack of screws. Rappel off trees, V threads or down climb to the right of the route (easy).

Easy climbing up a narrow iced up drainage far upstream on the LSR.

About 1 k northeast (upstream) of Hole in the Wall Falls. The route is on the left hand side (west bank).
Couple of screws.

Very secluded area. There are ice routes on both river banks. Lots of north facing routes which produces very reliable ice early and late into the season. There is some mixed with climbing on rhyolite rock of varying qualities. Stunningly beautiful location. Somewhat difficult to move around in this area due to the topography and problems with crossing the river. In a normal winter it is usually not difficult to move up and down the river on the ice.
